items.content_html:
Summary

Currently it's only noted that an empty string is returned when no port is included in the given url. This does not cover when a port is given, but with a protocol that has a matching default port. So new URL('http://localhost:80').port returns '', same with new URL('https://localhost:443').port, new URL('ssh://localhost:22').port, etc. Not sure if an example showing this should be added in the Examples section as well, but my assumption is that the note in the description is enough.

Also happy to take feedback on the wording, not sure if given port number is too explicit or protocol's default is too ambiguous.

Motivation

My assumption of what was returned when explicitly providing a port in a URL to parse was that it would populate regardless of protocol, so I think it's worthwhile to describe that difference.

Supporting details

N/A

Related issues

N/A

items.title: A note for empty string returned for default ports

items.content_html:
In the case of greater than, less than, and plus operators the link underlining makes the symbol look like another symbol with a different meaning (greater than looks like greater than or equal to, less than looks like less than or equal to, and plus looks like plus/minus). Placing the word after the symbol may help disambiguate the presentation.

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: Link formatting makes one symbol look like another

items.content_html:
This has been raised in #15118.

The idea here is double:

  • Reach consistency (we currently have: Void, None, undefined or {{jsxref("undefined")}}.
  • Explain clearly that no return value means that a JS undefined object is returned, and link to it for additional information. This will help beginners.
items.title: Update return value text when there is no returned value

items.content_html:
This adds a draft issue triage process for mdn/content.

I think one trick is discussing issues in enough detail to make good decisions, but still get through enough in 30 minutes. I'm especially worried that including a bit about "write an outline of how to fix it" will take too long but it does seem like it would be very useful to include it.

How many is "enough"? We average about 50 issues/week (and have a big backlog). But I hope that some number of incoming issues will just get fixed (or closed) anyway without going through triage.
items.title: Add triage process doc

Summary

Added a case that affects the containing block in chromium browsers.

Motivation

Spent a lot of time debugging a weird containing-block case, and it was caused by an ancestor having the backdrop-filter property (in chromium). Saw that it wasn't documented, so thought it would be helpful for others.

items.title: Add case that affects identifying containing block

items.content_html:
When considering inline elements their margin only is respected horizontally and not vertically.
The corrections were aimed at that mistake of saying that vertical margins are respected and also
that padding has restrictions which is not the case because all 4 paddings are respected although
they only cause displacement of elements horizontally.

Summary

Correct margin and padding mix up when considering their effects on inline elements

Motivation

The change helps to make the tutorial correct and to give readers the theoretical box model knowledge that matches the browser rendering.

Supporting details

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Correct mix up between margins and paddings

items.content_html:
Summary

made sections more consistent across the Learning HTML and Learning CSS Modules.

  • naming of the sections
  • adding missing sections that would normally always be present (e.g. article summaries)
  • adapting (text) content if necessary
  • catching some typos
  • making "In this module" sections uniform
    • there was a discussion #13781 where linking to the current page is giving a flaw and it shoudln't be done
    • but due to the fact that it was done like this almost everywhere - i also adapted it like this in a few places
    • i thought that would make it easier to fix the problem overall and result in fewer edge cases.

i would do the same for the other modules (e.g. Learn JavaScript) in further PRs when I continue to learn trough the modules (if desired of course).

Motivation

To keep things consistent.

Related issues

Fixes #13671

items.content_html:
Summary

I added OKLab color functions to CSS Functional Notation.

Motivation

They are part of CSS Color Modules 4.

Adding them to this list will fix Stylelint function-no-unknown since Stylelint uses this document as a source of all valid CSS function names.

Supporting details

Safari TP should support these functions.
